Award.AwardTitle: Statistical Models, Inference, and Computation for Multidimensional Time Series Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
It is now commonplace for data to be collected over time across multiple (often many) sources. Examples include the time signals across multiple brain regions arising from fMRI, ocean wave height series across multiple spatial locations collected from buoys or satellites, and the multiple economic indicators (GPD, unemployment, and so on) gathered over time by government agencies and other parties. Available techniques often either neglect temporal dependencies for such high-dimensional data arising from multiple sources or do not apply to situations when the number of sources is large. This research project aims to develop novel statistical modeling tools that can capture adequately both the temporal features of such data and also their dependencies across multiple sources. Such tools have the potential to greatly enhance knowledge gained from such data. With fMRI data, for example, proper accounting for temporal dependence and large number of brain regions may facilitate better distinction among various clinical categories (ADHD, autism, etc.). Understanding the temporal and spatial dependencies in wave height data can lead to better predictions of storm activity across the oceans, and further insight into economic activity is expected from improved analysis of multiple economic indicators.

The project aims at developing an integrated approach to analyzing large multidimensional time series data, including their statistical models, estimation, computation (algorithms), and practice. The research covers both short-range and long-range dependent multidimensional time series. For short-range dependent series, the focus is on sparse vector autoregressive and related models, dimension reduction, change point detection and some nonlinear models. The problems to be addressed concern regularization techniques, statistical significance, models exhibiting cyclical variations and other issues. Multidimensional long-range dependence is suggested as the important class complementing vector autoregressive and related short-range dependent series, thus gathering the two general classes of models employed in modern time series analysis. The goal is to develop a new methodology for multidimensional long-range dependent series with the so-called general phase, which controls the symmetry properties of multidimensional time series, in both linear and nonlinear settings. The developed methods should be useful across a wide range of areas, including neuroscience, oceanography and environmental sciences, geophysics, economics and finance, and others.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project advanced the practice and methodology for dealing with multidimensional time series data. This is the type of data that are collected over time across many interrelated sources, possibly for multiple individuals. Examples include fMRI data measuring temporal brain activity across its many regions of interest, as well as across individuals; various economic activity indicators collected over time, for one or many countries; multiple gene expression data for cells undergoing differentiation in time; real-time data from wearable devices monitoring one's health. The explosion of data gathering through new technologies and natural human interest in understanding changes in time make such data ubiquitous. Practical questions of interest concern forecasting such data into the future, exploring (possibly causal) relationships between the various sources, and describing individual multidimensional time series data as part of a larger population. 

In advancing methodology for dealing with such data, its various aspects were considered under the project. Modeling questions were studied in two important established settings, those of weak and strong temporal dependence. Continuous-valued time series (taking any numerical values) and discrete-valued time series (taking count values such as zero and one) were treated separately. Various models for source interdependence were based on network, factor and other structures. Special forms of temporal dependence, for example, related to periodicity and change points, were also considered. Across many of these considered settings, novel statistical models and mathematical tools were developed, typically supplemented by accompanying computer code that would allow other researchers to use it in their applications of interest.

In advancing the practice for dealing with such data, nearly all project 20+ papers were data-driven and considered applications. Some highlights of the considered applications include:

  • Modeling time series of major hurricane counts in the Atlantic and Pacific oceans, arguing for strong temporal and cross-ocean dependence. 
  • Modeling multiple day-to-day emotional experiences across individuals, arguing that population-based models perform better in forecasting at individual level.
  • Modeling brain connectivity from DTI data across time, to determine whether imaging data could help in signaling the progression of Alzheimer's disease.
  • Modeling change points in fMRI data, to detect times when individuals transition across different tasks or emotional states. 

Interest and relevance of time series data across a large number of sources and multiple individuals are expected to grow, with the work accomplished under the project providing another foundational layer for their successful analysis. 

Finally, a number of students, both undergraduate and graduate, and from underrepresented groups, were trained as part of the project, strengthening the workforce ready to engage in data analytic approaches to real-life problems.
